title: How to Make Aleppo Soap

steps.headline: Put on your safety gear.
steps.description: Making the soap requires working with lye, which is highly corrosive and can burn the skin on contact. Before you begin mixing up the soap, put on a pair of protective gloves and safety goggles just in case of splashing. It’s also a good idea to wear a long-sleeved shirt to protect your arms as well. For safety reasons, you shouldn’t allow children to help you make the soap.

steps.headline: Measure out the water in a heatproof container.
steps.description: It’s important to have precise measurements when you’re making soap, so it’s best to weigh the ingredients. Pour 1 ounce of distilled water into a heatproof container, and check that it weighs 28.34 grams on a digital kitchen scale.

steps.headline: Weigh the lye and add it to the water.
steps.description: Pour 0.65 ounces of lye (sodium hydroxide) into a separate container, and place it on the kitchen scale to ensure that it weighs 18.4 grams. Next, carefully, pour the lye into the distilled water. Make sure that the lye you’re using is labeled as 100% sodium hydroxide. You can find lye at some hardware stores in the drain cleaning section, but it’s widely available at online retailers that sell soap making supplies.

steps.headline: Stir the water and lye together well.
steps.description: As soon as you’ve added the lye to the distilled water, use a spatula to mix the two together. Continue stirring until the lye is completely dissolved. The mixture will get very warm and give off fumes quickly, so it’s best to work beside an open window. If possible, you may want to mix the water and lye together in your kitchen sink. That way, if there are any splashes or spills, they’ll be easier to clean up.

steps.headline: Allow the mixture to cool in a safe place.
steps.description: After the lye has dissolved and the solution has warmed up, set it in a safe, secure location. Let the mixture cool down for 30 to 40 minutes, so it reaches a temperature between 100 and 110°F (38 to 43°C). Make sure that the lye mixture is out of reach of children and pets. It’s a good idea to label the container too, so no one accidentally touches or tries to drink it. You can use a digital kitchen thermometer to test the mixture’s temperature.

steps.headline: Measure the oils and add them to the top of a double boiler.
steps.description: Pour 4 ounces extra virgin olive oil into a medium bowl, and make sure that it weighs 113.4 grams. Next, add 1 ounce of laurel berry fruit oil to the bowl, and check that it adds an extra 28.35 grams of weight on the scale. Place the bowl on top of a double boiler on the stove. Be sure to use laurel berry fruit oil, not bay laurel or laurel leaf essential oil. Laurel berry fruit oil can be difficult to find, but many online retailers sell it.

steps.headline: Heat the oils gently until they reach 90 to 100°F (32 to 38°C).
steps.description: Turn the burner on to low heat, so the oils begin to warm up. It should take about 5 to 7 minutes for the oils to reach the right temperature.

steps.headline: Remove the oils from the double boiler.
steps.description: Once the oils have reached the proper temperature, carefully lift the bowl out of the double boiler. Place it down on a heatproof surface, such as a trivet. It’s a good idea to place the trivet that you set the bowl on in your sink to catch any possible spills or splashes.

steps.headline: Pour the lye solution into the oils and blend until trace is reached.
steps.description: When the lye solution has reached the right temperature, carefully add it to the oils. Mix the solution until it becomes thick enough that when you lift the spoon out of the mixture, the drizzle leaves an imprint on the surface before sinking in, which is known as trace. You may find it easier to use an immersion blender to mix the soap until it reaches traces.

steps.headline: Add the soap mixture to the mold(s).
steps.description: The recipe makes about 10 ounces (283 grams) of soap. The number of molds that you’ll need will depend on how large they are. Smooth the soap in place with a spatula for an even surface. You can purchase soap molds at craft stores and online retailers that sell soapmaking supplies. Depending on your preference, you can choose smaller molds that form individual soap bars or a single large mold that makes a long bar that you can then slice into individual bars after it’s set. If you don’t have soap molds, you can use silicone baking molds.

steps.headline: Cover the molds with parchment paper and cardboard.
steps.description: To help insulate the soap as it dries, set a piece of parchment paper over each mold. Next, lay a sheet of cardboard over the paper to trap the heat further. Some molds come with lids, so you can just use them instead of the parchment paper and cardboard. If the area that you’re working in is cold, you may want to further insulate the molds with a blanket or towel.

steps.headline: Let the soap sit in the mods for 1 to 2 days.
steps.description: For the soap to set properly, they should sit in the mold for at least 24 hours. If you’re in a very humid location, though, it may take up to 48 for the soap to set.

steps.headline: Remove the soap from the molds and cure for several weeks.
steps.description: When the soap is fully set, carefully unmold it. If you’ve used a larger mold, you can cut the soap into bars. Because of the high amount of olive oil in the soap, it needs to cure for a fairly long time before you use it so let it sit out exposed to the air for at least 6 to 8 weeks. Curing the soap allows the water in it to evaporate so it becomes harder, which helps it last longer. It also helps the soap become gentler, so it doesn’t irritate the skin when you use it. Allowing the soap to cure for 6 months to a year can make it even better.
